description: Know that numbers that are not rational are called irrational. Understand informally that every number has a decimal expansion; for rational numbers show that the decimal expansion repeats eventually, and convert a decimal expansion which repeats eventually into a rational number.
teacherQuestion: How can you use division to compare and contrast rational and irrational numbers?

title: 8.NS.A.2
description: Use rational approximations of irrational numbers to compare the size of irrational numbers, locate them approximately on a number line diagram, and estimate the value of expressions (e.g., Ï€2).
teacherQuestion: How can estimation of rational numbers be used to compare relative size of quantities that include irrational numbers?

title: 8.EE.A.1
description: Know and apply the properties of integer exponents to generate equivalent numerical expressions.
teacherQuestion: How can properties of integer exponents be used to represent equivalent expressions?
studentQuestion:
Interpret, Exemplify, Summarize, Infer, Paraphrase,
Classify, Compare, Explain

title: 8.EE.A.2
description: Use square root and cube root symbols to represent solutions to equations of the form x2 = p and x3 = p, where p is a positive rational number. Evaluate square roots of small perfect squares and cube roots of small perfect cubes. Know that âˆš2 is irrational.
teacherQuestion: How can you use your understanding of perfect square and cube roots to compare rational and irrational numbers?
studentQuestion:
Interpret, Exemplify, Summarize, Infer, Paraphrase,
Classify, Compare, Explain

title: 8.EE.A.3
description: Use numbers expressed in the form of a single digit times an integer power of 10 to estimate very large or very small quantities, and to express how many times as much one is than the other.
teacherQuestion: How can you describe the parts of the scientific notation algorithm and use it to express very large and very small numbers?
studentQuestion: Implement, Carry out, Use, Execute

title: 8.EE.A.4
description: Perform operations with numbers expressed in scientific notation, including problems where both decimal and scientific notation are used. Use scientific notation and choose units of appropriate size for measurements of very large or very small quantities (e.g., use millimeters per year for seafloor spreading). Interpret scientific notation that has been generated by technology
teacherQuestion: How can scientific notation be used to solve problems?
studentQuestion: Implement, Carry out, Use, Execute

title: 8.EE.B.5
description: Graph proportional relationships, interpreting the unit rate as the slope of the graph. Compare two different proportional relationships represented in different ways.
teacherQuestion: How can a graph be used to demonstrate a proportional relationship and how can it be used to compare results of two different relationships?
studentQuestion: Compare, Organize, Deconstruct, Attribute, Outline, Structure, Integrate

title: 8.EE.B.6
description: Use similar triangles to explain why the slope m is the same between any two distinct points on a non-vertical line in the coordinate plane; derive the equation y = mx for a line through the origin and the equation y = mx + b for a line intercepting the vertical axis at b.
teacherQuestion: How can similar triangles be used to demonstrate equal slopes between any two points of a non-vertical line on the coordinate plane?
studentQuestion: Compare, Organize, Deconstruct, Attribute, Outline, Structure, Integrate

title: 8.EE.C.7
description: Solve linear equations in one variable.
teacherQuestion: How can you graph the solution to a linear equation in one variable on the coordinate plane?
studentQuestion:
Interpret, Exemplify, Summarize, Infer, Paraphrase,
Classify, Compare, Explain

title: 8.EE.C.7.A
description: Give examples of linear equations in one variable with one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solutions.
teacherQuestion: How an equation represent more than one solution?  No solutions?  Exactly one solution?
studentQuestion:
Interpret, Exemplify, Summarize, Infer, Paraphrase,
Classify, Compare, Explain

title: 8.EE.C.7.B
description: Solve linear equations with rational number coefficients, including equations whose solutions require expanding expressions using the distributive property and collecting like terms.
teacherQuestion: Compare the process of solving linear equations with whole number coefficients and those with rational coefficients.
studentQuestion:
Interpret, Exemplify, Summarize, Infer, Paraphrase,
Classify, Compare, Explain

title: 8.EE.C.8
description: Analyze and solve pairs of simultaneous linear equations.
teacherQuestion: How can two linear equations be solved at the same time?
studentQuestion: Compare, Organize, Deconstruct, Attribute, Outline, Structure, Integrate

title: 8.EE.C.8.A
description: Understand that solutions to a system of two linear equations in two variables correspond to points of intersection of their graphs, because points of intersection satisfy both equations simultaneously.
teacherQuestion: How can you illustrate the solution to a system of linear equations?
studentQuestion:
Interpret, Exemplify, Summarize, Infer, Paraphrase,
Classify, Compare, Explain

title: 8.EE.C.8.B
description: Solve systems of two linear equations in two variables algebraically, and estimate solutions by graphing the equations.
teacherQuestion: How can you show the similarities and differences between real-world applications of systems of linear equations and use graphing to determine value?
studentQuestion: Implement, Carry out, Use, Execute

title: 8.EE.C.8.C
description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems leading to two linear equations in two variables.
teacherQuestion: How can you use different solution strategies to solve real-world problems in two variables?
studentQuestion: Implement, Carry out, Use, Execute

title: 8.F.A.1
description: Understand that a function is a rule that assigns to each input exactly one output. The graph of a function is the set of ordered pairs consisting of an input and the corresponding output
teacherQuestion: How can you determine if a relation is a function?
studentQuestion:
Interpret, Exemplify, Summarize, Infer, Paraphrase,
Classify, Compare, Explain

title: 8.F.A.2
description: Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal descriptions).
teacherQuestion: How can different representations of functions be used to compare their properties?
studentQuestion: Check, Hypothesize, Critique, Experiment, Judge, Test, Detect, Monitor

title: 8.F.A.3
description: Interpret the equation y = mx + b as defining a linear function, whose graph is a straight line; give examples of functions that are not linear.
teacherQuestion: What components of a linear function can you invert and use to cite counterexamples?
studentQuestion: Design, Construct, Plan, Produce, Invent, Devise, Make

title: 8.F.B.4
description: Construct a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities. Determine the rate of change and initial value of the function from a description of a relationship or from two (x, y) values, including reading these from a table or from a graph. Interpret the rate of change and initial value of a linear function in terms of the situation it models, and in terms of its graph or a table of values.
teacherQuestion: How can you use the rules of algebra to rewrite equations, creating different meanings of real-world context and visa versa?
studentQuestion: Design, Construct, Plan, Produce, Invent, Devise, Make

title: 8.F.B.5
description: Describe qualitatively the functional relationship between two quantities by analyzing a graph (e.g., where the function is increasing or decreasing, linear or nonlinear). Sketch a graph that exhibits the qualitative features of a function that has been described verbally.
teacherQuestion: How can you use visual clues and estimation to determine relationships between two quantities?
studentQuestion: Design, Construct, Plan, Produce, Invent, Devise, Make

title: 8.G.A.1
description: Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations:
teacherQuestion: How can you use experiments to verify transformation properties?
studentQuestion: Compare, Organize, Deconstruct, Attribute, Outline, Structure, Integrate

title: 8.G.A.1.A
description: Lines are taken to lines, and line segments to line segments of the same length.

title: 8.G.A.1.B
description: Angles are taken to angles of the same measure.

studentQuestion: Recognize, List, Describe, Identify, Retrieve, Name, Locate, Find

title: 8.G.A.1.C
description: Parallel lines are taken to parallel lines.

studentQuestion: Recognize, List, Describe, Identify, Retrieve, Name, Locate, Find

title: 8.G.A.2
description: Understand that a two-dimensional figure is congruent to another if the second can be obtained from the first by a sequence of rotations, reflections, and translations; given two congruent figures, describe a sequence that exhibits the congruence between them.

studentQuestion:

Classify, Compare, Explain

title: 8.G.A.3
description: Describe the effect of dilations, translations, rotations, and reflections on two-dimensional figures using coordinates.
teacherQuestion: How can you use the language of geometry to describe a translation?
studentQuestion: Check, Hypothesize, Critique, Experiment, Judge, Test, Detect, Monitor

title: 8.G.A.4
description: Understand that a two-dimensional figure is similar to another if the second can be obtained from the first by a sequence of rotations, reflections, translations, and dilations; given two similar two-dimensional figures, describe a sequence that exhibits the similarity between them.
teacherQuestion: How can you perform an experiment to determine the relationship between a figure and it's translation?
studentQuestion:
Interpret, Exemplify, Summarize, Infer, Paraphrase,
Classify, Compare, Explain

title: 8.G.A.5
description: Use informal arguments to establish facts about the angle sum and exterior angle of triangles, about the angles created when parallel lines are cut by a transversal, and the angle-angle criterion for similarity of triangles.
teacherQuestion: How can you perform an experiment to determine the relationship between a figure and it's translation?
studentQuestion: Check, Hypothesize, Critique, Experiment, Judge, Test, Detect, Monitor

title: 8.G.B.6
description: Explain a proof of the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse.
teacherQuestion: How can an understanding of proportional relationships be used to visualize the Pythagorean Theorem?
studentQuestion:
Interpret, Exemplify, Summarize, Infer, Paraphrase,
Classify, Compare, Explain

title: 8.G.B.7
description: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to determine unknown side lengths in right triangles in real-world and mathematical problems in two and three dimensions.
teacherQuestion: How can the Pythagorean Theorem be used to determine side lengths of triangles?
studentQuestion: Implement, Carry out, Use, Execute

title: 8.G.B.8
description: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to find the distance between two points in a coordinate system.
teacherQuestion: How can the Pythagorean Theorem be used to determine side lengths of triangles on a coordinate plane?
studentQuestion: Implement, Carry out, Use, Execute

title: 8.G.C.9
description: Know the formulas for the volumes of cones, cylinders, and spheres and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
teacherQuestion: How can algorithms be used to find solutions to real-world and mathematical volume problems?
studentQuestion: Recognize, List, Describe, Identify, Retrieve, Name, Locate, Find

title: 8.SP.A.1
description: Construct and interpret scatter plots for bivariate measurement data to investigate patterns of association between two quantities. Describe patterns such as clustering, outliers, positive or negative association, linear association, and nonlinear association.
teacherQuestion: How can you use tables, scatter plots, and graphs to make decisions on real-world data questions?
studentQuestion: Compare, Organize, Deconstruct, Attribute, Outline, Structure, Integrate

title: 8.SP.A.2
description: Know that straight lines are widely used to model relationships between two quantitative variables.
teacherQuestion: How can you use tables, scatter plots, and graphs to make decisions on real-world data questions?
studentQuestion: Compare, Organize, Deconstruct, Attribute, Outline, Structure, Integrate

title: 8.SP.A.3
description: Use the equation of a linear model to solve problems in the context of bivariate measurement data, interpreting the slope and intercept.
teacherQuestion: How can you use tables, scatter plots, and graphs to make decisions on real-world data questions?
studentQuestion: Compare, Organize, Deconstruct, Attribute, Outline, Structure, Integrate

title: 8.SP.A.4
description: Understand that patterns of association can also be seen in bivariate categorical data by displaying frequencies and relative frequencies in a two-way table. Construct and interpret a two-way table summarizing data on two categorical variables collected from the same subjects. Use relative frequencies calculated for rows or columns to describe possible association between the two variables.
teacherQuestion: How can you use tables, scatter plots, and graphs to make decisions on real-world data questions?
studentQuestion: Check, Hypothesize, Critique, Experiment, Judge, Test, Detect, Monitor

title: HSN.RN.A.1
description: Explain how the definition of the meaning of rational exponents follows from extending the properties of integer exponents to those values, allowing for a notation for radicals in terms of rational exponents.
teacherQuestion: What is the difference between linear and exponential models?

title: HSN.RN.A.2
description: Rewrite expressions involving radicals and rational exponents using the properties of exponents.
teacherQuestion: How do the properties of exponents used to rewrite expressions?

title: HSN.RN.B.3
description: Explain why the sum or product of two rational numbers is rational; that the sum of a rational number and an irrational number is irrational; and that the product of a nonzero rational number and an irrational number is irrational.
teacherQuestion: How do the properties of rational and irrational numbers help to determine the results of sums and products?

title: HSN.Q.A.1
description: Use units as a way to understand problems and to guide the solution of multi-step problems; choose and interpret units consistently in formulas; choose and interpret the scale and the origin in graphs and data displays.
teacherQuestion: How can your understanding of units help make and confirm predictions and solve multi-step problems?

title: HSN.Q.A.2
description: Define appropriate quantities for the purpose of descriptive modeling.
teacherQuestion: How can checking your solutions help make better sense of quantitative problems?

title: HSN.Q.A.3
description: Choose a level of accuracy appropriate to limitations on measurement when reporting quantities.
teacherQuestion: How can careful unit analysis help make more accurate judgements in real-world problems?

title: HSN.CN.A.1
description: Know there is a complex number i such that i2 = -1, and every complex number has the form a + bi with a and b real.
teacherQuestion: How does knowing the form of complex numbers help perform operations?

title: HSN.CN.A.2
description: Use the relation i2 = -1 and the commutative, associative, and distributive properties to add, subtract, and multiply complex numbers.
teacherQuestion: How does knowing the differences between complex and real numbers help to solve complex number problems?

title: HSN.CN.A.3
description: Find the conjugate of a complex number; use conjugates to find moduli and quotients of complex numbers.
teacherQuestion: How are conjugates used to find moduli and quotients of complex numbers?

title: HSN.CN.B.4
description: Represent complex numbers on the complex plane in rectangular and polar form (including real and imaginary numbers), and explain why the rectangular and polar forms of a given complex number represent the same number.
teacherQuestion: Why do the rectangular and polar forms of a given complex number represent the same number?

title: HSN.CN.B.5
description: Represent addition, subtraction, multiplication, and conjugation of complex numbers geometrically on the complex plane; use properties of this representation for computation.
teacherQuestion: How does representing complex numbers geometrically on the complex plane help you understand addition, subtraction, multiplication, and conjugation of complex numbers?

title: HSN.CN.B.6
description: Calculate the distance between numbers in the complex plane as the modulus of the difference, and the midpoint of a segment as the average of the numbers at its endpoints.
teacherQuestion: How is calculating the distance and midpoint between two points in the complex plane, similar to calculating the distance and midpoint between two points in the coordinate plane?

title: HSN.CN.C.7
description: Solve quadratic equations with real coefficients that have complex solutions.
teacherQuestion: How does the graph of a quadratic with complex solutions compare to a graph with no complex solutions?

title: HSN.CN.C.8
description: Extend polynomial identities to the complex numbers. For example, rewrite x2 + 4 as (x + 2i)(x - 2i).
teacherQuestion: When would it be useful to rewrite an expression using complex numbers?

title: HSN.CN.C.9
description: Know the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra; show that it is true for quadratic polynomials.
teacherQuestion: How do you know the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra is true for all quadratic polynomials?

title: HSN.VM.A.1
description: Recognize vector quantities as having both magnitude and direction. Represent vector quantities by directed line segments, and use appropriate symbols for vectors and their magnitudes (e.g., v, |v|, ||v||, v).
teacherQuestion: What is a vector and how are they represented?

title: HSN.VM.A.2
description: Find the components of a vector by subtracting the coordinates of an initial point from the coordinates of a terminal point.
teacherQuestion: What are the components of a vector and how do you find them?

title: HSN.VM.A.3
description: Solve problems involving velocity and other quantities that can be represented by vectors.
teacherQuestion: How does representing a quantity as a vector help you interpret and solve real-world problems?

title: HSN.VM.B.4
description: Add and subtract vectors.
teacherQuestion: How can you represent vector addition/subtraction in the coordinate plane?

title: HSN.VM.B.4.A
description: Add vectors end-to-end, component-wise, and by the parallelogram rule. Understand that the magnitude of a sum of two vectors is typically not the sum of the magnitudes.
teacherQuestion: Why is it that magnitude of a sum of two vectors is typically not the sum of the magnitudes?

title: HSN.VM.B.4.B
description: Given two vectors in magnitude and direction form, determine the magnitude and direction of their sum.
teacherQuestion: How could you estimate the magnitude of the sum of two vectors?

title: HSN.VM.B.4.C
description: Understand vector subtraction v - w as v + (-w), where -w is the additive inverse of w, with the same magnitude as w and pointing in the opposite direction. Represent vector subtraction graphically by connecting the tips in the appropriate order, and perform vector subtraction component-wise.
teacherQuestion: How can you represent vector subtraction graphically?

title: HSN.VM.B.5
description: Multiply a vector by a scalar.
teacherQuestion: How does scalar multiplication affect the magnitude and direction of the vector?

title: HSN.VM.B.5.A
description: Represent scalar multiplication graphically by scaling vectors and possibly reversing their direction; perform scalar multiplication component-wise, e.g., as c(vx, vy) = (cvx, cvy).
teacherQuestion: How can you represent scalar multiplication of vectors graphically?

title: HSN.VM.B.5.B
description: Compute the magnitude of a scalar multiple cv using ||cv|| = |c|v. Compute the direction of cv knowing that when |c|v â‰  0, the direction of cv is either along v (for c > 0) or against v (for c < 0).
teacherQuestion: How does scalar multiplication affect the magnitude and direction of the vector?

title: HSN.VM.C.6
description: Use matrices to represent and manipulate data, e.g., to represent payoffs or incidence relationships in a network.
teacherQuestion: How can matrices be used to represent and manipulate data?

title: HSN.VM.C.7
description: Multiply matrices by scalars to produce new matrices, e.g., as when all of the payoffs in a game are doubled.
teacherQuestion: How is multiplying a matrix by a scalar similar to the distributive property?

title: HSN.VM.C.8
description: Add, subtract, and multiply matrices of appropriate dimensions.
teacherQuestion: When is it not possible to add/subtract/multiply two matrices? Why?

title: HSN.VM.C.9
description: Understand that, unlike multiplication of numbers, matrix multiplication for square matrices is not a commutative operation, but still satisfies the associative and distributive properties.
teacherQuestion: Why isn't multiplication for square matrices a commutative operation?

title: HSN.VM.C.10
description: Understand that the zero and identity matrices play a role in matrix addition and multiplication similar to the role of 0 and 1 in the real numbers. The determinant of a square matrix is nonzero if and only if the matrix has a multiplicative inverse.
teacherQuestion: How are the role of the zero and identity matrices similar to the role of 0 and 1 in real numbers?

title: HSN.VM.C.11
description: Multiply a vector (regarded as a matrix with one column) by a matrix of suitable dimensions to produce another vector. Work with matrices as transformations of vectors.
teacherQuestion: When isn't multiplication of a vector by a matrix possible? Why?

title: HSN.VM.C.12
description: Work with 2 Ã— 2 matrices as a transformations of the plane, and interpret the absolute value of the determinant in terms of area.
teacherQuestion: How can you use 2 x 2 matrices to perform transformations in the coordinate plane?

title: HSA.SSE.A.1
description: Interpret expressions that represent a quantity in terms of its context.
teacherQuestion: How does each part of this expression relate to the context of the situation it models?

title: HSA.SSE.A.1.A
description: Interpret parts of an expression, such as terms, factors, and coefficients.
teacherQuestion: What are the parts that make up an expression?

title: HSA.SSE.A.1.B
description: Interpret complicated expressions by viewing one or more of their parts as a single entity.
teacherQuestion: Can you break the expression into smaller parts to make it easier to understand? If so, what does each part represent within the context of the situation it models?

title: HSA.SSE.A.2
description: Use the structure of an expression to identify ways to rewrite it. For example, see x4 - y4 as (x2)2 - (y2)2, thus recognizing it as a difference of squares that can be factored as (x2 - y2)(x2 + y2).
teacherQuestion: When may it be useful to rewrite expressions in equivalent forms?

title: HSA.SSE.B.3
description: Choose and produce an equivalent form of an expression to reveal and explain properties of the quantity represented by the expression.
teacherQuestion: When might one apply algebraic properties to generate equivalent expressions?

title: HSA.SSE.B.3.A
description: Factor a quadratic expression to reveal the zeros of the function it defines.
teacherQuestion: How are the factors of a quadratic expression related to the graph of the function?

title: HSA.SSE.B.3.B
description: Complete the square in a quadratic expression to reveal the maximum or minimum value of the function it defines.
teacherQuestion: When is completing the square the best method to use on a quadratic expression? Why?

title: HSA.SSE.B.3.C
description: Use the properties of exponents to transform expressions for exponential functions.
teacherQuestion: How can you apply the properties of exponents to create equivalent expressions? What aspect of the context does each exponential function highlight?

title: HSA.SSE.B.4
description: Derive the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series (when the common ratio is not 1), and use the formula to solve problems.
teacherQuestion: How can you derive the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series?

title: HSA.APR.A.1
description: Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under the operations of addition, subtraction, and multiplication; add, subtract, and multiply polynomials.
teacherQuestion: How is the addition/subtraction/multiplication of polynomials similar/different to the that of integers?

title: HSA.APR.B.2
description: Know and apply the Remainder Theorem: For a polynomial p(x) and a number a, the remainder on division by x - a is p(a), so p(a) = 0 if and only if (x - a) is a factor of p(x).
teacherQuestion: If (x-a) is a factor of p(x), how do we know that p(a) = 0 must hold true?

title: HSA.APR.B.3
description: Identify zeros of polynomials when suitable factorizations are available, and use the zeros to construct a rough graph of the function defined by the polynomial.
teacherQuestion: How can you use zeros of a polynomial to sketch a graph of the function defined by that polynomial?

title: HSA.APR.C.4
description: Prove polynomial identities and use them to describe numerical relationships. For example, the polynomial identity (x2 + y2)2 = (x2 - y2)2 + (2xy)2 can be used to generate Pythagorean triples.
teacherQuestion: How can we prove this polynomial identity, and what are some of it's applications?

title: HSA.APR.C.5
description: Know and apply the Binomial Theorem for the expansion of (x + y)n in powers of x and y for a positive integer n, where x and y are any numbers, with coefficients determined for example by Pascal's Triangle.
teacherQuestion: Why is the Binomial Theorem useful?

title: HSA.APR.D.6
description: Rewrite simple rational expressions in different forms; write a(x)/b(x) in the form q(x) + r(x)/b(x), where a(x), b(x), q(x), and r(x) are polynomials with the degree of r(x) less than the degree of b(x), using inspection, long division, or, for the more complicated examples, a computer algebra system.
teacherQuestion: Why would one want to rewrite simple rational expressions in different forms? How can you be sure the forms are equivalent?

title: HSA.APR.D.7
description: Understand that rational expressions form a system analogous to the rational numbers, closed under addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division by a nonzero rational expression; add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational expressions.
teacherQuestion: How is addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division of rational expressions similar/different from that of rational numbers?

title: HSA.CED.A.1
description: Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use them to solve problems.
teacherQuestion: How can you model this situation with an equation or inequality? What does each part of the equation/inequality represent?

title: HSA.CED.A.2
description: Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities; graph equations on coordinate axes with labels and scales.
teacherQuestion: What do the slope and y-intercept of the graph represent in terms of the context of the problem?

title: HSA.CED.A.3
description: Represent constraints by equations or inequalities, and by systems of equations and/or inequalities, and interpret solutions as viable or nonviable options in a modeling context.
teacherQuestion: What are the constraints to this model and how do we represent them graphically?

title: HSA.CED.A.4
description: Rearrange formulas to highlight a quantity of interest, using the same reasoning as in solving equations.
teacherQuestion: When might you want to rearrange formulas to highlight certain quantities of interest?

title: HSA.REI.A.1
description: Explain each step in solving a simple equation as following from the equality of numbers asserted at the previous step, starting from the assumption that the original equation has a solution. Construct a viable argument to justify a solution method.
teacherQuestion: How can you justify each step you took to arrive at your solution?

title: HSA.REI.A.2
description: Solve simple rational and radical equations in one variable, and give examples showing how extraneous solutions may arise.
teacherQuestion: What are extraneous solutions and when may one arise?

title: HSA.REI.B.3
description: Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including equations with coefficients represented by letters.
teacherQuestion: How can you represent your solution on a coordinate plane or a number line?

title: HSA.REI.B.4
description: Solve quadratic equations in one variable.
teacherQuestion: How are the number of possible solutions to a quadratic equation similar/different to the number of possible solutions to a linear equation? How can you model this graphically?

title: HSA.REI.B.4.A
description: Use the method of completing the square to transform any quadratic equation in x into an equation of the form (x - p)2 = q that has the same solutions. Derive the quadratic formula from this form.
teacherQuestion: How can we use the method of completing the square to derive the quadratic formula?

title: HSA.REI.B.4.B
description: Solve quadratic equations by inspection (e.g., for x2 = 49), taking square roots, completing the square, the quadratic formula and factoring, as appropriate to the initial form of the equation. Recognize when the quadratic formula gives complex solutions and write them as a Â± bi for real numbers a and b.
teacherQuestion: How can you predict when the quadratic formula will produce complex solutions?

title: HSA.REI.C.5
description: Prove that, given a system of two equations in two variables, replacing one equation by the sum of that equation and a multiple of the other produces a system with the same solutions.
teacherQuestion: When given a system of two equation in two variables, if you replace one equation by the sum of that equation and a multiple of the other, why will the new system always have the same solutions?

title: HSA.REI.C.6
description: Solve systems of linear equations exactly and approximately (e.g., with graphs), focusing on pairs of linear equations in two variables.
teacherQuestion: How can you verify your solution graphically/algebraically?

title: HSA.REI.C.7
description: Solve a simple system consisting of a linear equation and a quadratic equation in two variables algebraically and graphically. For example, find the points of intersection between the line y = -3x and the circle x2 + y2 = 3.
teacherQuestion: How can you use a graph of the linear equation and quadratic equation to predict the algebraic solution to the system of equations?

title: HSA.REI.C.8
description: Represent a system of linear equations as a single matrix equation in a vector variable.
teacherQuestion: Why might it be useful to represent a system of linear equations as a single equation in a vector variable?

title: HSA.REI.C.9
description: Find the inverse of a matrix if it exists and use it to solve systems of linear equations (using technology for matrices of dimension 3 Ã— 3 or greater).
teacherQuestion: Why is it necessary to find the inverse of a matrix representing a system of linear equations, when trying to solve the system?

title: HSA.REI.D.10
description: Understand that the graph of an equation in two variables is the set of all its solutions plotted in the coordinate plane, often forming a curve (which could be a line).
teacherQuestion: What does the graph of an equation represent?

title: HSA.REI.D.11
description: Explain why the x-coordinates of the points where the graphs of the equations y = f(x) and y = g(x) intersect are the solutions of the equation f(x) = g(x); find the solutions approximately, e.g., using technology to graph the functions, make tables of values, or find successive approximations. Include cases where f(x) and/or g(x) are linear, polynomial, rational, absolute value, exponential, and logarithmic functions.
teacherQuestion: Why are the x-coordinates of the points where the graphs of the equations y = f(x) and y = g(x) intersect, the solutions of the equation f(x) = g(x)?

title: HSA.REI.D.12
description: Graph the solutions to a linear inequality in two variables as a half-plane (excluding the boundary in the case of a strict inequality), and graph the solution set to a system of linear inequalities in two variables as the intersection of the corresponding half-planes.
teacherQuestion: How can you verify a point is a solution to a system of inequalities graphically?

title: HSF.IF.A.1
description: Understand that a function from one set (called the domain) to another set (called the range) assigns to each element of the domain exactly one element of the range.
teacherQuestion: What is a function?

title: HSF.IF.A.2
description: Use function notation, evaluate functions for inputs in their domains, and interpret statements that use function notation in terms of a context.
teacherQuestion: How can evaluating functions for inputs in their domain help us predict the range of the function?

title: HSF.IF.A.3
description: Recognize that sequences are functions, sometimes defined recursively, whose domain is a subset of the integers.
teacherQuestion: Can a sequence be a function? Will all sequences be functions? How do you know?

title: HSF.IF.B.4
description: For a function that models a relationship between two quantities, interpret key features of graphs and tables in terms of the quantities, and sketch graphs showing key features given a verbal description of the relationship.
teacherQuestion: Explain how the key features of a graph (intercepts; intervals where the function is increasing, decreasing, positive, or negative; relative maximums and minimums; symmetries; end behavior; and periodicity) model the verbal description of the relationship.

title: HSF.IF.B.5
description: Relate the domain of a function to its graph and, where applicable, to the quantitative relationship it describes.
teacherQuestion: Explain how the domain of the graph represents the quantitative relationship it describes.

title: HSF.IF.B.6
description: Calculate and interpret the average rate of change of a function (presented symbolically or as a table) over a specified interval. Estimate the rate of change from a graph.
teacherQuestion: How does the average rate of change of a function over specified intervals, help you better understand the relationship it models?

title: HSF.IF.C.7
description: Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features of the graph, by hand in simple cases and using technology for more complicated cases.
teacherQuestion: What are the key features of the graph and how will they allow you to predict what it may look like?

title: HSF.IF.C.7.A
description: Graph linear and quadratic functions and show intercepts, maxima, and minima.
teacherQuestion: How can intercepts help you predict what a linear graph may look like? How can maxima/minima and roots help you predict what a quadratic graph may look like?

title: HSF.IF.C.7.B
description: Graph square root, cube root, and piecewise-defined functions, including step functions and absolute value functions.
teacherQuestion: What are the key features of the graph and how will they allow you to predict what it may look like?

title: HSF.IF.C.7.C
description: Graph polynomial functions, identifying zeros when suitable factorizations are available, and showing end behavior.
teacherQuestion: How can determining zeros of a polynomial help you predict what the graph of the polynomial function may look like?

title: HSF.IF.C.7.D
description: Graph rational functions, identifying zeros and asymptotes when suitable factorizations are available, and showing end behavior.
teacherQuestion: How can identifying zeros and asymptotes help you predict what the graph of a rational function may look like?

title: HSF.IF.C.7.E
description: Graph exponential and logarithmic functions, showing intercepts and end behavior, and trigonometric functions, showing period, midline, and amplitude.
teacherQuestion: What are the key similarities/differences between exponential graphs and logarithmic graphs?

title: HSF.IF.C.8
description: Write a function defined by an expression in different but equivalent forms to reveal and explain different properties of the function.
teacherQuestion: How did defining the expression in different but equivalent forms highlight a different property of the function? What are other instances when this process may be useful?

title: HSF.IF.C.8.A
description: Use the process of factoring and completing the square in a quadratic function to show zeros, extreme values, and symmetry of the graph, and interpret these in terms of a context.
teacherQuestion: How do the zeros, maximum/minimum, and symmetry of the graph relate to the relationship it models?

title: HSF.IF.C.8.B
description: Use the properties of exponents to interpret expressions for exponential functions. For example, identify percent rate of change in functions such as y = (1.02)áµ—, y = (0.97)áµ—, y = (1.01)12áµ—, y = (1.2)áµ—/10, and classify them as representing exponential growth or decay.
teacherQuestion: How are the properties of exponents useful when classifying an expression as one of exponential growth or decay?

title: HSF.IF.C.9
description: Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal descriptions)
teacherQuestion: For a given input, which function will have the largest output? Justify your answer using the information from the equation(s), graphs(s), table(s), and/or verbal description.

title: HSF.BF.A.1
description: Write a function that describes a relationship between two quantities.
teacherQuestion: How does the function model the relationship described?

title: HSF.BF.A.1.A
description: Determine an explicit expression, a recursive process, or steps for calculation from a context.
teacherQuestion: How can you justify your expression/process/steps using the context of the problem?

title: HSF.BF.A.1.B
description: Combine standard function types using arithmetic operations.
teacherQuestion: How can you combine two or more functions to model the given situation?

title: HSF.BF.A.1.C
description: Compose functions. For example, if T(y) is the temperature in the atmosphere as a function of height, and h(t) is the height of a weather balloon as a function of time, then T(h(t)) is the temperature at the location of the weather balloon as a function of time.
teacherQuestion: How does the graph of the composed function relate to the graphs of each individual function?

title: HSF.BF.A.2
description: Write arithmetic and geometric sequences both recursively and with an explicit formula, use them to model situations, and translate between the two forms.
teacherQuestion: How is each part of the recursive and explicit formula related to the situation it models?

title: HSF.BF.B.3
description: Identify the effect on the graph of replacing f(x) by f(x) + k, k f(x), f(kx), and f(x + k) for specific values of k (both positive and negative); find the value of k given the graphs. Experiment with cases and illustrate an explanation of the effects on the graph using technology. Include recognizing even and odd functions from their graphs and algebraic expressions for them.
teacherQuestion: How does 'k' effect the graph of f(x) when replacing f(x) with f(x)+k, kf(x), f(kx), and f(x +k)?

title: HSF.BF.B.4
description: Find inverse functions.
teacherQuestion: How does the graph of an inverse function compare to the graph of the original function?

title: HSF.BF.B.4.A
description: Solve an equation of the form f(x) = c for a simple function f that has an inverse and write an expression for the inverse. For example, f(x) =2 x3 or f(x) = (x+1)/(x-1) for x â‰  1.
teacherQuestion: How is the process of finding an inverse function algebraically related to finding an inverse of the function graphically?

title: HSF.BF.B.4.B
description: Verify by composition that one function is the inverse of another.
teacherQuestion: How can you prove that a function is an inverse of another?

title: HSF.BF.B.4.C
description: Read values of an inverse function from a graph or a table, given that the function has an inverse.
teacherQuestion: When given values of a function, how can you determine values contained in its inverse?

title: HSF.BF.B.4.D
description: Produce an invertible function from a non-invertible function by restricting the domain.
teacherQuestion: When could a function be non-invertible? How do you get around these limitations?

title: HSF.BF.B.5
description: Understand the inverse relationship between exponents and logarithms and use this relationship to solve problems involving logarithms and exponents.
teacherQuestion: Explain why the logb x  and  b^x are inverses of one another.

title: HSF.LE.A.1
description: Distinguish between situations that can be modeled with linear functions and with exponential functions.
teacherQuestion: What is the difference between linear and exponential growth?

title: HSF.LE.A.1.A
description: Prove that linear functions grow by equal differences over equal intervals, and that exponential functions grow by equal factors over equal intervals.
teacherQuestion: How can you prove that a functions growth is linear/quadratic?

title: HSF.LE.A.1.B
description: Recognize situations in which one quantity changes at a constant rate per unit interval relative to another.
teacherQuestion: What are examples of linear growth in real life? How do you know it is growing linearly?

title: HSF.LE.A.1.C
description: Recognize situations in which a quantity grows or decays by a constant percent rate per unit interval relative to another.
teacherQuestion: What are examples of exponential growth in real life? How do you know it is growing exponentially?

title: HSF.LE.A.2
description: Construct linear and exponential functions, including arithmetic and geometric sequences, given a graph, a description of a relationship, or two input-output pairs (include reading these from a table).
teacherQuestion: What are examples of linear growth in real life? How do you know it is growing linearly?

title: HSF.LE.A.3
description: Observe using graphs and tables that a quantity increasing exponentially eventually exceeds a quantity increasing linearly, quadratically, or (more generally) as a polynomial function.
teacherQuestion: If you were given a choice between $1,000,000 and a magic penny that doubled in value each day, which would you choose and why?

title: HSF.LE.A.4
description: For exponential models, express as a logarithm the solution to abct = d where a, c, and d are numbers and the base b is 2, 10, or e; evaluate the logarithm using technology.
teacherQuestion: Why are logarithms necessary to determine the solution to the exponential model?

title: HSF.LE.B.5
description: Interpret the parameters in a linear or exponential function in terms of a context.
teacherQuestion: How can you explain the parameters in the (linear/exponential) function in terms of the context of the situation it models?

title: HSF.TF.A.1
description: Understand radian measure of an angle as the length of the arc on the unit circle subtended by the angle.
teacherQuestion: How can you use what you know about the relationship between the radian measure of an angle and the length of the arc to determine the arc length?

title: HSF.TF.A.2
description: Explain how the unit circle in the coordinate plane enables the extension of trigonometric functions to all real numbers, interpreted as radian measures of angles traversed counterclockwise around the unit circle.
teacherQuestion: How does the unit circle in the coordinate plane enable the extension of trigonometric functions to all real numbers?

title: HSF.TF.A.3
description: Use special triangles to determine geometrically the values of sine, cosine, tangent for Ï€/3, Ï€/4 and Ï€/6, and use the unit circle to express the values of sine, cosine, and tangent for x, Ï€ + x, and 2Ï€ - x in terms of their values for x, where x is any real number.
teacherQuestion: How do special right triangles (30-60-90 & 45-45-90) help you interpret the unit circle?

title: HSF.TF.A.4
description: Use the unit circle to explain symmetry (odd and even) and periodicity of trigonometric functions.
teacherQuestion: Why are trigonometric functions symmetric and periodic?

title: HSF.TF.B.5
description: Choose trigonometric functions to model periodic phenomena with specified amplitude, frequency, and midline.
teacherQuestion: What are some real- life situations that can be modeled by trigonometric functions? What about the situation indicates that it could be modeled by a trigonometric function?

title: HSF.TF.B.6
description: Understand that restricting a trigonometric function to a domain on which it is always increasing or always decreasing allows its inverse to be constructed.
teacherQuestion: Why does restricting the domain of a trigonometric function allow for an inverse to be constructed?

title: HSF.TF.B.7
description: Use inverse functions to solve trigonometric equations that arise in modeling contexts; evaluate the solutions using technology, and interpret them in terms of the context.
teacherQuestion: What does the solution of the trigonometric equation mean in terms of the context it models?

title: HSF.TF.C.8
description: Prove the Pythagorean identity sin2(Î¸) + cos2(Î¸) = 1 and use it to find sin(Î¸), cos(Î¸), or tan(Î¸) given sin(Î¸), cos(Î¸), or tan(Î¸) and the quadrant of the angle.
teacherQuestion: How do you know that sin2(Î¸) + cos2(Î¸) = 1 will always hold true?

title: HSF.TF.C.9
description: Prove the addition and subtraction formulas for sine, cosine, and tangent and use them to solve problems.
teacherQuestion: If you assume that the addition formula for sine is true, how can you use it to prove the subtraction formula for sine, the addition formula for cosine, and the subtraction formula for cosine?

title: HSG.CO.A.1
description: Know precise definitions of angle, circle, perpendicular line, parallel line, and line segment, based on the undefined notions of point, line, distance along a line, and distance around a circular arc.
teacherQuestion: How can you use your understanding of a point, line, distance, and arc length to derive a definition for angle, circle, perpendicular line, parallel line, and line segment?

title: HSG.CO.A.2
description: Represent transformations in the plane using, e.g., transparencies and geometry software; describe transformations as functions that take points in the plane as inputs and give other points as outputs. Compare transformations that preserve distance and angle to those that do not (e.g., translation versus horizontal stretch).
teacherQuestion: Which transformations preserve distance and angle?

title: HSG.CO.A.3
description: Given a rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid, or regular polygon, describe the rotations and reflections that carry it onto itself.
teacherQuestion: How can you carry an image onto itself using rotations and/or reflections?

title: HSG.CO.A.4
description: Develop definitions of rotations, reflections, and translations in terms of angles, circles, perpendicular lines, parallel lines, and line segments.
teacherQuestion: How can you use your knowledge of angles, circles, perpendicular lines, parallel lines, and line segments to develop definitions of rotations, reflections, and translations?

title: HSG.CO.A.5
description: Given a geometric figure and a rotation, reflection, or translation, draw the transformed figure using, e.g., graph paper, tracing paper, or geometry software. Specify a sequence of transformations that will carry a given figure onto another.
teacherQuestion: How many unique sequences of transformations can you come up with that will take image A to image B?

title: HSG.CO.B.6
description: Use geometric descriptions of rigid motions to transform figures and to predict the effect of a given rigid motion on a given figure; given two figures, use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to decide if they are congruent.
teacherQuestion: How can you use geometric descriptions of rigid motions to transform figures and to predict the effect of a given rigid motion on a given figure?

title: HSG.CO.B.7
description: Use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to show that two triangles are congruent if and only if corresponding pairs of sides and corresponding pairs of angles are congruent.
teacherQuestion: How can you use definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to show that two triangles are congruent if and only if corresponding pairs of sides and corresponding pairs of angles are congruent?

title: HSG.CO.B.8
description: Explain how the criteria for triangle congruence (ASA, SAS, and SSS) follow from the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions.
teacherQuestion: How do the criteria for triangle congruence follow from the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motion?

title: HSG.CO.C.9
description: Prove theorems about lines and angles. Theorems include: vertical angles are congruent; when a transversal crosses parallel lines, alternate interior angles are congruent and corresponding angles are congruent; points on a perpendicular bisector of a line segment are exactly those equidistant from the segment's endpoints.
teacherQuestion: How can you prove that vertical angles, alternate interior angles, and corresponding angle are congruent?

title: HSG.CO.C.10
description: Prove theorems about triangles. Theorems include: measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180Â°; base angles of isosceles triangles are congruent; the segment joining midpoints of two sides of a triangle is parallel to the third side and half the length; the medians of a triangle meet at a point.
teacherQuestion: How do you know the interior angle sum of a triangle will always be 180 degrees? How can you use this property to determine the interior angle sum of other regular polygons?

title: HSG.CO.C.11
description: Prove theorems about parallelograms. Theorems include: opposite sides are congruent, opposite angles are congruent, the diagonals of a parallelogram bisect each other, and conversely, rectangles are parallelograms with congruent diagonals.
teacherQuestion: How can you prove that opposite sides and opposite angles are congruent?

title: HSG.CO.D.12
description: Make formal geometric constructions with a variety of tools and methods (compass and straightedge, string, reflective devices, paper folding, dynamic geometric software, etc.).
teacherQuestion: Why is it useful to know how to make geometric constructions?

title: HSG.CO.D.13
description: Construct an equilateral triangle, a square, and a regular hexagon inscribed in a circle.
teacherQuestion: How can you construct an equilateral triangle, square, and a regular hexagon inscribed in a circle?

title: HSG.SRT.A.1
description: Verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a center and a scale factor:
teacherQuestion: How can you verify that dilations preserve angle measures?

title: HSG.SRT.A.1.A
description: A dilation takes a line not passing through the center of the dilation to a parallel line, and leaves a line passing through the center unchanged.
teacherQuestion: How can you prove that a dilation takes a line not passing through the center of the dilation to a parallel line, and leaves a line passing through the center unchanged?

title: HSG.SRT.A.1.B
description: The dilation of a line segment is longer or shorter in the ratio given by the scale factor.
teacherQuestion: If a dilation of a line segment is longer or shorter in the ratio given by the scale factor, how would the scale factor affect the area of a rectangular figure formed from 4 line segments?

title: HSG.SRT.A.2
description: Given two figures, use the definition of similarity in terms of similarity transformations to decide if they are similar; explain using similarity transformations the meaning of similarity for triangles as the equality of all corresponding pairs of angles and the proportionality of all corresponding pairs of sides.
teacherQuestion: How can we prove that 2 triangles are similar?

title: HSG.SRT.A.3
description: Use the properties of similarity transformations to establish the AA criterion for two triangles to be similar.
teacherQuestion: How can you use the properties of similarity transformations to explain the AA criterion for two triangles to be similar?

title: HSG.SRT.B.4
description: Prove theorems about triangles. Theorems include: a line parallel to one side of a triangle divides the other two proportionally, and conversely; the Pythagorean Theorem proved using triangle similarity.
teacherQuestion: How can you use similar triangles to prove the Pythagorean Theorem?

title: HSG.SRT.B.5
description: Use congruence and similarity criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures.
teacherQuestion: What are real life situations in which knowing the properties of congruent/similar triangles would be useful?

title: HSG.SRT.C.6
description: Understand that by similarity, side ratios in right triangles are properties of the angles in the triangle, leading to definitions of trigonometric ratios for acute angles.
teacherQuestion: What is the sine ratio and how does it help you determine the value of unknown side lengths and angle measures in a right triangle?

title: HSG.SRT.C.7
description: Explain and use the relationship between the sine and cosine of complementary angles.
teacherQuestion: What is the relationship between the sine and cosine of complementary angles?

title: HSG.SRT.C.8
description: Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.
teacherQuestion: How can the Pythagorean Theorem and trigonometric ratios help you determine the measure of unknown sides and angles in right triangles?

title: HSG.SRT.D.9
description: Derive the formula A = 1/2 ab sin(C) for the area of a triangle by drawing an auxiliary line from a vertex perpendicular to the opposite side.
teacherQuestion: How can you use the known area formula for a triangle (A= 1/2 * base * height)  to derive the formula A = 1/2 ab sinÂ©?

title: HSG.SRT.D.10
description: Prove the Laws of Sines and Cosines and use them to solve problems.
teacherQuestion: How can you prove the Law of Sines and Cosines?

title: HSG.SRT.D.11
description: Understand and apply the Law of Sines and the Law of Cosines to find unknown measurements in right and non-right triangles (e.g., surveying problems, resultant forces).
teacherQuestion: How are the Law of Sines and the Law of Cosines useful in finding unknown measures in triangles?

title: HSG.C.A.1
description: Prove that all circles are similar.
teacherQuestion: Based on your prior knowledge of similarity, would you assume all circles are similar? why or why not?

title: HSG.C.A.2
description: Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, and chords. Include the relationship between central, inscribed, and circumscribed angles; inscribed angles on a diameter are right angles; the radius of a circle is perpendicular to the tangent where the radius intersects the circle.
teacherQuestion: How can you find missing angle measurements within a circle using the intersecting chord theorem?

title: HSG.C.A.3
description: Construct the inscribed and circumscribed circles of a triangle, and prove properties of angles for a quadrilateral inscribed in a circle.
teacherQuestion: How do angle bisectors and perpendicular bisectors help us to construct the inscribed and circumscribed circles of a triangle?

title: HSG.C.A.4
description: Construct a tangent line from a point outside a given circle to the circle.
teacherQuestion: How will a compass and ruler assist us in constructing a tangent line from a point outside a given circle to the circle?

title: HSG.C.B.5
description: Derive using similarity the fact that the length of the arc intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius, and define the radian measure of the angle as the constant of proportionality; derive the formula for the area of a sector.
teacherQuestion: How can you use your knowledge of similarity to help you show that the length of the arc intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius?

title: HSG.GPE.A.1
description: Derive the equation of a circle of given center and radius using the Pythagorean Theorem; complete the square to find the center and radius of a circle given by an equation.
teacherQuestion: How does your knowledge of the Pythagorean Theorem help you derive the equation of a circle of given center and radius?

title: HSG.GPE.A.2
description: Derive the equation of a parabola given a focus and directrix.
teacherQuestion: What are a focus and directrix of a parabola and how to they help you derive its equation?

title: HSG.GPE.A.3
description: Derive the equations of ellipses and hyperbolas given the foci, using the fact that the sum or difference of distances from the foci is constant.
teacherQuestion: How can you use the fact that the sum or difference of distances from the foci is constant, to derive the equation of ellipses and hyperbolas given foci?

title: HSG.GPE.B.4
description: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically. For example, prove or disprove that a figure defined by four given points in the coordinate plane is a rectangle; prove or disprove that the point (1, âˆš3) lies on the circle centered at the origin and containing the point (0, 2).
teacherQuestion: What evidence do you need to cite in order to prove your claim?

title: HSG.GPE.B.5
description: Prove the slope criteria for parallel and perpendicular lines and use them to solve geometric problems (e.g., find the equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to a given line that passes through a given point).
teacherQuestion: How can you prove that two lines are parallel/perpendicular?

title: HSG.GPE.B.6
description: Find the point on a directed line segment between two given points that partitions the segment in a given ratio.
teacherQuestion: How can you use the midpoint formula to help you predict the position of the point?

title: HSG.GPE.B.7
description: Use coordinates to compute perimeters of polygons and areas of triangles and rectangles, e.g., using the distance formula.
teacherQuestion: How does the placement of the polygon on a coordinate plane help you determine it's perimeter and area?

title: HSG.GMD.A.1
description: Give an informal argument for the formulas for the circumference of a circle, area of a circle, volume of a cylinder, pyramid, and cone. Use dissection arguments, Cavalieri's principle, and informal limit arguments.
teacherQuestion: How can you use the known formula for the area of a circle to derive the volume formulas for a cylinder and cone?

title: HSG.GMD.A.2
description: Give an informal argument using Cavalieri's principle for the formulas for the volume of a sphere and other solid figures.
teacherQuestion: How can you use Cavalieri's principle to derive the volume formula of a sphere and other solid figures?

title: HSG.GMD.A.3
description: Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.
teacherQuestion: What are some real life scenarios in which knowing the volume of a cylinder, pyramid, cone, or sphere would be useful?

title: HSG.GMD.B.4
description: Identify the shapes of two-dimensional cross-sections of three-dimensional objects, and identify three-dimensional objects generated by rotations of two-dimensional objects.
teacherQuestion: What will the shape of the two-dimensional cross-section be if we cut this object in half?

title: HSG.MG.A.1
description: Use geometric shapes, their measures, and their properties to describe objects (e.g., modeling a tree trunk or a human torso as a cylinder).
teacherQuestion: What geometric shape can we use to model this object? What are other objects we can model with this geometric shape?

title: HSG.MG.A.2
description: Apply concepts of density based on area and volume in modeling situations (e.g., persons per square mile, BTUs per cubic foot).
teacherQuestion: What are some real life scenarios in which calculating density would provide you with useful information?

title: HSG.MG.A.3
description: Apply geometric methods to solve design problems (e.g., designing an object or structure to satisfy physical constraints or minimize cost; working with typographic grid systems based on ratios).
teacherQuestion: How could we design a structure to satisfy the given constraints?

title: HSS.ID.A.1
description: Represent data with plots on the real number line (dot plots, histograms, and box plots).
teacherQuestion: What plot (dot plot, histogram, box plot) is the most useful to evaluate the given data set? Why?

title: HSS.ID.A.2
description: Use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data distribution to compare center (median, mean) and spread (interquartile range, standard deviation) of two or more different data sets.
teacherQuestion: What do the measures of distribution tell you about the data set?

title: HSS.ID.A.3
description: Interpret differences in shape, center, and spread in the context of the data sets, accounting for possible effects of extreme data points (outliers).
teacherQuestion: What are possible causes for outliers in the data set?

title: HSS.ID.A.4
description: Use the mean and standard deviation of a data set to fit it to a normal distribution and to estimate population percentages. Recognize that there are data sets for which such a procedure is not appropriate. Use calculators, spreadsheets, and tables to estimate areas under the normal curve.
teacherQuestion: How does fitting a data set to a normal distribution help you better understand the data? When is it not appropriate to fit the data to a normal distribution?

title: HSS.ID.B.5
description: Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the context of the data (including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies). Recognize possible associations and trends in the data.
teacherQuestion: What key observations can you make from the two way table provided? How do these observations relate to the context of the data?

title: HSS.ID.B.6
description: Represent data on two quantitative variables on a scatter plot, and describe how the variables are related.
teacherQuestion: What does the scatter plot tell you about how the two variables are related?

title: HSS.ID.B.6.A
description: Fit a function to the data; use functions fitted to data to solve problems in the context of the data. Use given functions or choose a function suggested by the context. Emphasize linear, quadratic, and exponential models.
teacherQuestion: How does your function allow you to predict future data points?

title: HSS.ID.B.6.B
description: Informally assess the fit of a function by plotting and analyzing residuals.
teacherQuestion: Using evidence to support your claim, explain how well your function fits the data set.

title: HSS.ID.B.6.C
description: Fit a linear function for a scatter plot that suggests a linear association.
teacherQuestion: What are important measures to know when fitting a linear function for a scatter plot that suggests a linear association?

title: HSS.ID.C.7
description: Interpret the slope (rate of change) and the intercept (constant term) of a linear model in the context of the data.
teacherQuestion: What do the slope and intercept mean in terms of the context of the linear relationship modeled?

title: HSS.ID.C.8
description: Compute (using technology) and interpret the correlation coefficient of a linear fit.
teacherQuestion: When is a correlation coefficient a useful measure to know?

title: HSS.ID.C.9
description: Distinguish between correlation and causation.
teacherQuestion: What is the difference between a correlation and a causation?

title: HSS.IC.A.1
description: Understand statistics as a process for making inferences about population parameters based on a random sample from that population.
teacherQuestion: How do you use statistics in your daily lives?

title: HSS.IC.A.2
description: Decide if a specified model is consistent with results from a given data-generating process, e.g., using simulation.
teacherQuestion: How do you know if a specified model is consistent with results given from a data-generating process?

title: HSS.IC.B.3
description: Recognize the purposes of and differences among sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies; explain how randomization relates to each.
teacherQuestion: How does randomization relate to sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies?

title: HSS.IC.B.4
description: Use data from a sample survey to estimate a population mean or proportion; develop a margin of error through the use of simulation models for random sampling.
teacherQuestion: How can you use data from a sample to estimate a population mean or proportion? What could cause errors in this estimate?

title: HSS.IC.B.5
description: Use data from a randomized experiment to compare two treatments; use simulations to decide if differences between parameters are significant.
teacherQuestion: How can you use data from a sample to estimate a population mean or proportion? What could cause errors in this estimate?

title: HSS.IC.B.6
description: Evaluate reports based on data.
teacherQuestion: How could you design an experiment to compare two treatments? How do you know if the differences between parameters are significant?

title: HSS.CP.A.1
description: Describe events as subsets of a sample space (the set of outcomes) using characteristics (or categories) of the outcomes, or as unions, intersections, or complements of other events ("or," "and," "not").
teacherQuestion: What are all possible outcomes that could occur?

title: HSS.CP.A.2
description: Understand that two events A and B are independent if the probability of A and B occurring together is the product of their probabilities, and use this characterization to determine if they are independent.
teacherQuestion: How can you use probability to prove that two events are independent of one another?

title: HSS.CP.A.3
description: Understand the conditional probability of A given B as P(A and B)/P(B), and interpret independence of A and B as saying that the conditional probability of A given B is the same as the probability of A, and the conditional probability of B given A is the same as the probability of B.
teacherQuestion: How can you use your understanding of conditional probability to decide if two events are independent of one another?

title: HSS.CP.A.4
description: Construct and interpret two-way frequency tables of data when two categories are associated with each object being classified. Use the two-way table as a sample space to decide if events are independent and to approximate conditional probabilities.
teacherQuestion: How can you use a two-way frequency table to determine if two events are independent?

title: HSS.CP.A.5
description: Recognize and explain the concepts of conditional probability and independence in everyday language and everyday situations.
teacherQuestion: What are some real life situations in which you would be interested in the conditional probability of an event?

title: HSS.CP.B.6
description: Find the conditional probability of A given B as the fraction of B's outcomes that also belong to A, and interpret the answer in terms of the model.
teacherQuestion: How could you illustrate the conditional probability of A given B using a square model?

title: HSS.CP.B.7
description: Apply the Addition Rule, P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B), and interpret the answer in terms of the model.
teacherQuestion: How do you know that the Addition Rule, P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B), will always hold true?

title: HSS.CP.B.8
description: Apply the general Multiplication Rule in a uniform probability model, P(A and B) = P(A)P(B|A) = P(B)P(A|B), and interpret the answer in terms of the model.
teacherQuestion: How do you know that the general Multiplication Rule in a uniform probability model, P(A and B) = P(A)P(B|A) = P(B)P(A|B), will always hold true?

title: HSS.CP.B.9
description: Use permutations and combinations to compute probabilities of compound events and solve problems.
teacherQuestion: How does identifying if a situation should be modeled with a permutation or a combination affect the probability of a compound event?

title: HSS.MD.A.1
description: Define a random variable for a quantity of interest by assigning a numerical value to each event in a sample space; graph the corresponding probability distribution using the same graphical displays as for data distributions.
teacherQuestion: How does your graph model the likelihood of events in the scenario it represents?

title: HSS.MD.A.2
description: Calculate the expected value of a random variable; interpret it as the mean of the probability distribution.
teacherQuestion: How does determining the mean of the probability distribution help inform your decision making process?

title: HSS.MD.A.3
description: Develop a probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample space in which theoretical probabilities can be calculated; find the expected value.
teacherQuestion: If you are asked to take a multiple choice test that you are not prepared for and have to guess on all 5 questions, 4 options each, how likely is it that you would pass the test (60% +)?

title: HSS.MD.A.4
description: Develop a probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample space in which probabilities are assigned empirically; find the expected value.
teacherQuestion: What information would you need to know in order to predict how many students, out of 10 randomly selected, own their own computer?

title: HSS.MD.B.5
description: Weigh the possible outcomes of a decision by assigning probabilities to payoff values and finding expected values.
teacherQuestion: How can you use probability to help you make decisions in your daily life?

title: HSS.MD.B.5.A
description: Find the expected payoff for a game of chance. For example, find the expected winnings from a state lottery ticket or a game at a fast-food restaurant.
teacherQuestion: How likely is it that a basketball player makes both free throws in a 1 and 1 opportunity?

title: HSS.MD.B.5.B
description: Evaluate and compare strategies on the basis of expected values.
teacherQuestion: How do the expected values help you compare these strategies?

title: HSS.MD.B.6
description: Use probabilities to make fair decisions (e.g., drawing by lots, using a random number generator).
teacherQuestion: What experiment could you run to model this event and allow you to collect data to inform your decision?

title: HSS.MD.B.7
description: Analyze decisions and strategies using probability concepts (e.g., product testing, medical testing, pulling a hockey goalie at the end of a game).
teacherQuestion: In what ways could companies use probability to predict the success of a new product?

title: RL.6.1
description: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
teacherQuestion: What evidence can you find to support your claim?

title: RL.6.2
description: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
teacherQuestion: What is the author trying to say? Which details in the text convey the central idea?

title: RL.6.3
description: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
teacherQuestion: What happened in the story? Describe the problem and how it was resolved in the story.

title: RL.7.1
description: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

title: RL.7.2
description: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.

title: RL.7.3
description: Analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).

title: RL.8.1
description: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

title: RL.8.2
description: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.

title: RL.8.3
description: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.

title: RL.9-10.1
description: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

title: RL.9-10.2
description: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of the text.

title: RL.9-10.3
description: Analyze how complex characters (e.g., those with multiple or conflicting motivations) develop over the course of a text, interact with other characters, and advance the plot or develop the theme.

title: RL.11-12.1
description: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain.

title: RL.11-12.2
description: Determine two or more themes or central ideas of a text and analyze their development over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to produce a complex account; provide an objective summary of the text.

title: RL.11-12.3
description: Analyze the impact of the author's choices regarding how to develop and relate elements of a story or drama (e.g., where a story is set, how the action is ordered, how the characters are introduced and developed).

title: RL.6.4
description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone
teacherQuestion: What words/phrases show the tone of the text? How does figurative language affect the meaning of the text?

title: RL.6.5
description: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.
teacherQuestion: How does the story develop over the text?

title: RL.6.6
description: Explain how an author develops the point of view of the narrator or speaker in a text.
teacherQuestion: How does the author develop the narrator's or speaker's point of view?

title: RL.7.4
description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of rhymes and other repetitions of sounds (e.g., alliteration) on a specific verse or stanza of a poem or section of a story or drama.

title: RL.7.5
description: Analyze how a drama's or poem's form or structure (e.g., soliloquy, sonnet) contributes to its meaning

title: RL.7.6
description: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the points of view of different characters or narrators in a text.

title: RL.8.4
description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.

title: RL.8.5
description: Compare and contrast the structure of two or more texts and analyze how the differing structure of each text contributes to its meaning and style.

title: RL.8.6
description: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.

title: RL.9-10.4
description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the cumulative impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone (e.g., how the language evokes a sense of time and place; how it sets a formal or informal tone).

title: RL.9-10.5
description: Analyze how an author's choices concerning how to structure a text, order events within it (e.g., parallel plots), and manipulate time (e.g., pacing, flashbacks) create such effects as mystery, tension, or surprise.

title: RL.9-10.6
description: Analyze a particular point of view or cultural experience reflected in a work of literature from outside the United States, drawing on a wide reading of world literature.

title: RL.11-12.4
description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including words with multiple meanings or language that is particularly fresh, engaging, or beautiful. (Include Shakespeare as well as other authors.)

title: RL.11-12.5
description: Analyze how an author's choices concerning how to structure specific parts of a text (e.g., the choice of where to begin or end a story, the choice to provide a comedic or tragic resolution) contribute to its overall structure and meaning as well as its aesthetic impact.

title: RL.11-12.6
description: Analyze a case in which grasping a point of view requires distinguishing what is directly stated in a text from what is really meant (e.g., satire, sarcasm, irony, or understatement).

title: RL.6.7
description: Compare and contrast the experience of reading a story, drama, or poem to listening to or viewing an audio, video, or live version of the text, including contrasting what they "see" and "hear" when reading the text to what they perceive when they listen or watch.
teacherQuestion: What is the difference between reading, watching, and/or listening to a text?

title: RL.6.8
description: (RL.6.8 not applicable to literature)

title: RL.6.9
description: Compare and contrast texts in different forms or genres (e.g., stories and poems; historical novels and fantasy stories) in terms of their approaches to similar themes and topics.
teacherQuestion: Describe different genres of texts and compare how they tell stories differently.

title: RL.7.7
description: Compare and contrast a written story, drama, or poem to its audio, filmed, staged, or multimedia version, analyzing the effects of techniques unique to each medium (e.g., lighting, sound, color, or camera focus and angles in a film).

title: RL.7.8
