description: (RL.7.8 not applicable to literature)

title: RL.7.9
description: Compare and contrast a fictional portrayal of a time, place, or character and a historical account of the same period as a means of understanding how authors of fiction use or alter history.

title: RL.8.7
description: Analyze the extent to which a filmed or live production of a story or drama stays faithful to or departs from the text or script, evaluating the choices made by the director or actors.

title: RL.8.8
description: (RL.8.8 not applicable to literature)

title: RL.8.9
description: Analyze how a modern work of fiction draws on themes, patterns of events, or character types from myths, traditional stories, or religious works such as the Bible, including describing how the material is rendered new.

title: RL.9-10.7
description: Analyze the representation of a subject or a key scene in two different artistic mediums, including what is emphasized or absent in each treatment (e.g., Auden's "MusÃ©e des Beaux Arts" and Breughel's Landscape with the Fall of Icarus).

title: RL.9-10.8
description: (RL.9-10.8 not applicable to literature)

title: RL.9-10.9
description: Analyze how an author draws on and transforms source material in a specific work (e.g., how Shakespeare treats a theme or topic from Ovid or the Bible or how a later author draws on a play by Shakespeare).

title: RL.11-12.7
description: Analyze multiple interpretations of a story, drama, or poem (e.g., recorded or live production of a play or recorded novel or poetry), evaluating how each version interprets the source text. (Include at least one play by Shakespeare and one play by an American dramatist.)

title: RL.11-12.8
description: (RL.11-12.8 not applicable to literature)

title: RL.11-12.9
description: Demonstrate knowledge of eighteenth-, nineteenth- and early-twentieth-century foundational works of American literature, including how two or more texts from the same period treat similar themes or topics.

title: RL.6.10
description: By the end of the year, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, in the grades 6-8 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.
teacherQuestion: What kind of text would you like to read next? Why?

title: RL.7.10
description: By the end of the year, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, in the grades 6-8 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.

title: RL.8.10
description: By the end of the year, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the high end of grades 6-8 text complexity band independently and proficiently.

title: RL.9-10.10
description: By the end of grade 9, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, in the grades 9-10 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range. By the end of grade 10, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the high end of the grades 9-10 text complexity band independently and proficiently.

title: RL.11-12.10
description: By the end of grade 11, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, in the grades 11-CCR text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range. By the end of grade 12, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the high end of the grades 11-CCR text complexity band independently and proficiently.

title: RI.6.1
description: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
teacherQuestion: What is the author trying to say? Which details in the text convey the central idea?

title: RI.6.2
description: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
teacherQuestion: Create a summary of the text using important facts, not your own opinion.

title: RI.6.3
description: Analyze in detail how a key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, and elaborated in a text (e.g., through examples or anecdotes).
teacherQuestion: How did the main character change over the course of the story?

title: RI.7.1
description: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

title: RI.7.2
description: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.

title: RI.7.3
description: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).

title: RI.8.1
description: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

title: RI.8.2
description: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.

title: RI.8.3
description: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, or categories).

title: RI.9-10.1
description: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

title: RI.9-10.2
description: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of the text.

title: RI.9-10.3
description: Analyze how the author unfolds an analysis or series of ideas or events, including the order in which the points are made, how they are introduced and developed, and the connections that are drawn between them.

title: RI.11-12.1
description: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain.

title: RI.11-12.2
description: Determine two or more central ideas of a text and analyze their development over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to provide a complex analysis; provide an objective summary of the text.

title: RI.11-12.3
description: Analyze a complex set of ideas or sequence of events and explain how specific individuals, ideas, or events interact and develop over the course of the text.

title: RI.6.4
description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings.
teacherQuestion: Which words helped you to understand the author's message?

title: RI.6.5
description: Analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, chapter, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the ideas.
teacherQuestion: How does the paragraph fit into the main structure of the text?

title: RI.6.6
description: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
teacherQuestion: What is the author's point of view? How is it developed throughout the text?

title: RI.7.4
description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.

title: RI.7.5
description: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.

title: RI.7.6
description: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.

title: RI.8.4
description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.

title: RI.8.5
description: Analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.

title: RI.8.6
description: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.

title: RI.9-10.4
description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the cumulative impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone (e.g., how the language of a court opinion differs from that of a newspaper).

title: RI.9-10.5
description: Analyze in detail how an author's ideas or claims are developed and refined by particular sentences, paragraphs, or larger portions of a text (e.g., a section or chapter).

title: RI.9-10.6
description: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how an author uses rhetoric to advance that point of view or purpose.

title: RI.11-12.4
description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term or terms over the course of a text (e.g., how Madison defines faction in Federalist No. 10).

title: RI.11-12.5
description: Analyze and evaluate the effectiveness of the structure an author uses in his or her exposition or argument, including whether the structure makes points clear, convincing, and engaging.

title: RI.11-12.6
description: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text in which the rhetoric is particularly effective, analyzing how style and content contribute to the power, persuasiveness or beauty of the text.

title: RI.6.7
description: Integrate information presented in different media or formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively) as well as in words to develop a coherent understanding of a topic or issue.
teacherQuestion: How did each type of media make the message clear? What do you understand about the topic after working will the different kinds of media or formats?

title: RI.6.8
description: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and evidence from claims that are not.
teacherQuestion: Which claim is valid and which is not? Why?

title: RI.6.9
description: Compare and contrast one author's presentation of events with that of another (e.g., a memoir written by and a biography on the same person).
teacherQuestion: Which presentation of the topic did you like better? Why?

title: RI.7.7
description: Compare and contrast a text to an audio, video, or multimedia version of the text, analyzing each medium's portrayal of the subject (e.g., how the delivery of a speech affects the impact of the words).

title: RI.7.8
description: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.

title: RI.7.9
description: Analyze how two or more authors writing about the same topic shape their presentations of key information by emphasizing different evidence or advancing different interpretations of facts.

title: RI.8.7
description: Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of using different mediums (e.g., print or digital text, video, multimedia) to present a particular topic or idea.

title: RI.8.8
description: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.

title: RI.8.9
description: Analyze a case in which two or more texts provide conflicting information on the same topic and identify where the texts disagree on matters of fact or interpretation.

title: RI.9-10.7
description: Analyze various accounts of a subject told in different mediums (e.g., a person's life story in both print and multimedia), determining which details are emphasized in each account.

title: RI.9-10.8
description: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is valid and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; identify false statements and fallacious reasoning.

title: RI.9-10.9
description: Analyze seminal U.S. documents of historical and literary significance (e.g., Washington's Farewell Address, the Gettysburg Address, Roosevelt's Four Freedoms speech, King's "Letter from Birmingham Jail"), including how they address related themes and concepts.

title: RI.11-12.7
description: Integrate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in different media or formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively) as well as in words in order to address a question or solve a problem.

title: RI.11-12.8
description: Delineate and evaluate the reasoning in seminal U.S. texts, including the application of constitutional principles and use of legal reasoning (e.g., in U.S. Supreme Court majority opinions and dissents) and the premises, purposes, and arguments in works of public advocacy (e.g., The Federalist, presidential addresses).

title: RI.11-12.9
description: Analyze seventeenth-, eighteenth-, and nineteenth-century foundational U.S. documents of historical and literary significance (including The Declaration of Independence, the Preamble to the Constitution, the Bill of Rights, and Lincoln's Second Inaugural Address) for their themes, purposes, and rhetorical features.

title: RI.6.10
description: By the end of the year, read and comprehend literary nonfiction in the grades 6-8 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.
teacherQuestion: Which book was your favorite? Why?

title: RI.7.10
description: By the end of the year, read and comprehend literary nonfiction in the grades 6-8 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.

title: RI.8.10
description: By the end of the year, read and comprehend literary nonfiction at the high end of the grades 6-8 text complexity band independently and proficiently.

title: RI.9-10.10
description: By the end of grade 9, read and comprehend literary nonfiction in the grades 9-10 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range. By the end of grade 10, read and comprehend literary nonfiction at the high end of the grades 9-10 text complexity band independently and proficiently.

title: RI.11-12.10
description: By the end of grade 11, read and comprehend literary nonfiction in the grades 11-CCR text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range. By the end of grade 12, read and comprehend literary nonfiction at the high end of the grades 11-CCR text complexity band independently and proficiently.

title: W.6.1
description: Write arguments to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence.
teacherQuestion: Make a claim and use evidence to support it in writing.

title: W.6.1.A
description: Introduce claim(s) and organize the reasons and evidence clearly.
teacherQuestion: What is the claim? Why?

title: W.6.1.B
description: Support claim(s) with clear reasons and relevant evidence, using credible sources and demonstrating an understanding of the topic or text.
teacherQuestion: What reasons to you have to support your claim?

title: W.6.1.C
description: Use words, phrases, and clauses to clarify the relationships among claim(s) and reasons.
teacherQuestion: Which words/phrases can you use to connect your reasons and support your claim?

title: W.6.1.D
description: Establish and maintain a formal style.
teacherQuestion: How can you check to see if you have written in a formal style?

title: W.6.1.E
description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from the argument presented.
teacherQuestion: Does your conclusion support your argument?

title: W.6.2
description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
teacherQuestion: Which ideas will you write about?

title: W.6.2.A
description: Introduce a topic; organize ideas, concepts, and information, using strategies such as definition, classification, comparison/contrast, and cause/effect; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., charts, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.
teacherQuestion: How can you introduce your topic and organize your ideas?

title: W.6.2.B
description: Develop the topic with relevant facts, definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples.
teacherQuestion: Which facts help develop your topic?

title: W.6.2.C
description: Use appropriate transitions to clarify the relationships among ideas and concepts.
teacherQuestion: Which words/ phrases in your writing show the relationships among ideas and concepts?

title: W.6.2.D
description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic.
teacherQuestion: Which words have you used in your writing that only apply to your topic?

title: W.6.2.E
description: Establish and maintain a formal style.
teacherQuestion: How can you tell if your style of writing is formal?

title: W.6.2.F
description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from the information or explanation presented.
teacherQuestion: What is your conclusion?

title: W.6.3
description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, relevant descriptive details, and well-structured event sequences.
teacherQuestion: What are you writing about?

title: W.6.3.A
description: Engage and orient the reader by establishing a context and introducing a narrator and/or characters; organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally and logically.
teacherQuestion: Describe the setting and characters in your story.

title: W.6.3.B
description: Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, and description, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.
teacherQuestion: How will you introduce the reader to the problem in your story?

title: W.6.3.C
description: Use a variety of transition words, phrases, and clauses to convey sequence and signal shifts from one time frame or setting to another.
teacherQuestion: Which words/phrases will you use in your story to transition from one time or place to another?

title: W.6.3.D
description: Use precise words and phrases, relevant descriptive details, and sensory language to convey experiences and events.
teacherQuestion: How did you make the details of your story come alive through language?

title: W.6.3.E
description: Provide a conclusion that follows from the narrated experiences or events.
teacherQuestion: What happened at the end?

title: W.7.1
description: Write arguments to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence.

title: W.7.1.A
description: Introduce claim(s), acknowledge alternate or opposing claims, and organize the reasons and evidence logically.

title: W.7.1.B
description: Support claim(s) with logical reasoning and relevant evidence, using accurate, credible sources and demonstrating an understanding of the topic or text.

title: W.7.1.C
description: Use words, phrases, and clauses to create cohesion and clarify the relationships among claim(s), reasons, and evidence.

title: W.7.1.D
description: Establish and maintain a formal style.

title: W.7.1.E
description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument presented.

title: W.7.2
description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.

title: W.7.2.A
description: Introduce a topic clearly, previewing what is to follow; organize ideas, concepts, and information, using strategies such as definition, classification, comparison/contrast, and cause/effect; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., charts, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.

title: W.7.2.B
description: Develop the topic with relevant facts, definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples.

title: W.7.2.C
description: Use appropriate transitions to create cohesion and clarify the relationships among ideas and concepts.

title: W.7.2.D
description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic.

title: W.7.2.E
description: Establish and maintain a formal style.

title: W.7.2.F
description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented.

title: W.7.3
description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, relevant descriptive details, and well-structured event sequences.

title: W.7.3.A
description: Engage and orient the reader by establishing a context and point of view and introducing a narrator and/or characters; organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally and logically.

title: W.7.3.B
description: Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, and description, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.

title: W.7.3.C
description: Use a variety of transition words, phrases, and clauses to convey sequence and signal shifts from one time frame or setting to another.

title: W.7.3.D
description: Use precise words and phrases, relevant descriptive details, and sensory language to capture the action and convey experiences and events.

title: W.7.3.E
description: Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on the narrated experiences or events.

title: W.8.1
description: Write arguments to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence

title: W.8.1.A
description: Introduce claim(s), acknowledge and distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and organize the reasons and evidence logically.

title: W.8.1.B
description: Support claim(s) with logical reasoning and relevant evidence, using accurate, credible sources and demonstrating an understanding of the topic or text.

title: W.8.1.C
description: Use words, phrases, and clauses to create cohesion and clarify the relationships among claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.

title: W.8.1.D
description: Establish and maintain a formal style.

title: W.8.1.E
description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument presented.

title: W.8.2
description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.

title: W.8.2.A
description: Introduce a topic clearly, previewing what is to follow; organize ideas, concepts, and information into broader categories; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., charts, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.

title: W.8.2.B
description: Develop the topic with relevant, well-chosen facts, definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples.

title: W.8.2.C
description: Use appropriate and varied transitions to create cohesion and clarify the relationships among ideas and concepts.

title: W.8.2.D
description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic.

title: W.8.2.E
description: Establish and maintain a formal style.

title: W.8.2.F
description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented.

title: W.8.3
description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, relevant descriptive details, and well-structured event sequences.

title: W.8.3.A
description: Engage and orient the reader by establishing a context and point of view and introducing a narrator and/or characters; organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally and logically.

title: W.8.3.B
description: Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, and reflection, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.

title: W.8.3.C
description: Use a variety of transition words, phrases, and clauses to convey sequence, signal shifts from one time frame or setting to another, and show the relationships among experiences and events.

title: W.8.3.D
description: Use precise words and phrases, relevant descriptive details, and sensory language to capture the action and convey experiences and events.

title: W.8.3.E
description: Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on the narrated experiences or events.

title: W.9-10.1
description: Write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence.

title: W.9-10.1.A
description: Introduce precise claim(s), distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and create an organization that establishes clear relationships among claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.

title: W.9-10.1.B
description: Develop claim(s) and counterclaims fairly, supplying evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both in a manner that anticipates the audience's knowledge level and concerns.

title: W.9-10.1.C
description: Use words, phrases, and clauses to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims.

title: W.9-10.1.D
description: Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

title: W.9-10.1.E
description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument presented.

title: W.9-10.2
description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine and convey complex ideas, concepts, and information clearly and accurately through the effective selection, organization, and analysis of content.

title: W.9-10.2.A
description: Introduce a topic; organize complex ideas, concepts, and information to make important connections and distinctions; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.

title: W.9-10.2.B
description: Develop the topic with well-chosen, relevant, and sufficient facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic.

title: W.9-10.2.C
description: Use appropriate and varied transitions to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships among complex ideas and concepts.

title: W.9-10.2.D
description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to manage the complexity of the topic.

title: W.9-10.2.E
description: Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

title: W.9-10.2.F
description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic).

title: W.9-10.3
description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, well-chosen details, and well-structured event sequences.

title: W.9-10.3.A
description: Engage and orient the reader by setting out a problem, situation, or observation, establishing one or multiple point(s) of view, and introducing a narrator and/or characters; create a smooth progression of experiences or events.

title: W.9-10.3.B
description: Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, reflection, and multiple plot lines, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.

title: W.9-10.3.C
description: Use a variety of techniques to sequence events so that they build on one another to create a coherent whole.

title: W.9-10.3.D
description: Use precise words and phrases, telling details, and sensory language to convey a vivid picture of the experiences, events, setting, and/or characters.

title: W.9-10.3.E
description: Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on what is experienced, observed, or resolved over the course of the narrative.

title: W.11-12.1
description: Write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence.

title: W.11-12.1.A
description: Introduce precise, knowledgeable claim(s), establish the significance of the claim(s), distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and create an organization that logically sequences claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.

title: W.11-12.1.B
description: Develop claim(s) and counterclaims fairly and thoroughly, supplying the most relevant evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both in a manner that anticipates the audience's knowledge level, concerns, values, and possible biases.

title: W.11-12.1.C
description: Use words, phrases, and clauses as well as varied syntax to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims.

title: W.11-12.1.D
description: Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

title: W.11-12.1.E
description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument presented.

title: W.11-12.2
description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine and convey complex ideas, concepts, and information clearly and accurately through the effective selection, organization, and analysis of content.

title: W.11-12.2.A
description: Introduce a topic; organize complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.

title: W.11-12.2.B
description: Develop the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic.

title: W.11-12.2.C
description: Use appropriate and varied transitions and syntax to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships among complex ideas and concepts.

title: W.11-12.2.D
description: Use precise language, domain-specific vocabulary, and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic.

title: W.11-12.2.E
description: Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

title: W.11-12.2.F
description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic).

title: W.11-12.3
description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, well-chosen details, and well-structured event sequences.

title: W.11-12.3.A
description: Engage and orient the reader by setting out a problem, situation, or observation and its significance, establishing one or multiple point(s) of view, and introducing a narrator and/or characters; create a smooth progression of experiences or events.

title: W.11-12.3.B
description: Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, reflection, and multiple plot lines, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.

title: W.11-12.3.C
description: Use a variety of techniques to sequence events so that they build on one another to create a coherent whole and build toward a particular tone and outcome (e.g., a sense of mystery, suspense, growth, or resolution).

title: W.11-12.3.D
description: Use precise words and phrases, telling details, and sensory language to convey a vivid picture of the experiences, events, setting, and/or characters.

title: W.11-12.3.E
description: Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on what is experienced, observed, or resolved over the course of the narrative.

title: W.6.4
description: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.
teacherQuestion: What is the writing task asking you to do?

title: W.6.5
description: With some guidance and support from peers and adults, develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach.
teacherQuestion: How will you plan your writing? What is the difference between revising and editing?

title: W.6.6
description: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce and publish writing as well as to interact and collaborate with others; demonstrate sufficient command of keyboarding skills to type a minimum of three pages in a single sitting.
teacherQuestion: How will you use the Internet to bring your writing to an authentic audience?

title: W.7.4
description: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

title: W.7.5
description: With some guidance and support from peers and adults, develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on how well purpose and audience have been addressed.

title: W.7.6
description: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce and publish writing and link to and cite sources as well as to interact and collaborate with others, including linking to and citing sources.

title: W.8.4
description: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

title: W.8.5
description: With some guidance and support from peers and adults, develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on how well purpose and audience have been addressed.

title: W.8.6
description: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce and publish writing and present the relationships between information and ideas efficiently as well as to interact and collaborate with others.

title: W.9-10.4
description: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

title: W.9-10.5
description: Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience.

title: W.9-10.6
description: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products, taking advantage of technology's capacity to link to other information and to display information flexibly and dynamically.

title: W.11-12.4
description: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

title: W.11-12.5
description: Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience.

title: W.11-12.6
description: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information.

title: W.6.7
description: Conduct short research projects to answer a question, drawing on several sources and refocusing the inquiry when appropriate.
teacherQuestion: What are you researching?

title: W.6.8
description: Gather relevant information from multiple print and digital sources; assess the credibility of each source; and quote or paraphrase the data and conclusions of others while avoiding plagiarism and providing basic bibliographic information for sources.

title: W.6.9
description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

title: W.6.9.A
description: Apply grade 6 Reading standards to literature (e.g., "Compare and contrast texts in different forms or genres [e.g., stories and poems; historical novels and fantasy stories] in terms of their approaches to similar themes and topics").

title: W.6.9.B
description: Apply grade 6 Reading standards to literary nonfiction (e.g., "Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and evidence from claims that are not").

title: W.7.7
description: Conduct short research projects to answer a question, drawing on several sources and generating additional related, focused questions for further research and investigation.

title: W.7.8
description: Gather relevant information from multiple print and digital sources, using search terms effectively; assess the credibility and accuracy of each source; and quote or paraphrase the data and conclusions of others while avoiding plagiarism and following a standard format for citation.

title: W.7.9
description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

title: W.7.9.A
description: Apply grade 7 Reading standards to literature (e.g., "Compare and contrast a fictional portrayal of a time, place, or character and a historical account of the same period as a means of understanding how authors of fiction use or alter history").

title: W.7.9.B
description: Apply grade 7 Reading standards to literary nonfiction (e.g. "Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims").

title: W.8.7
description: Conduct short research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question), drawing on several sources and generating additional related, focused questions that allow for multiple avenues of exploration.

title: W.8.8
description: Gather relevant information from multiple print and digital sources, using search terms effectively; assess the credibility and accuracy of each source; and quote or paraphrase the data and conclusions of others while avoiding plagiarism and following a standard format for citation.

title: W.8.9
description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

title: W.8.9.A
description: Apply grade 8 Reading standards to literature (e.g., "Analyze how a modern work of fiction draws on themes, patterns of events, or character types from myths, traditional stories, or religious works such as the Bible, including describing how the material is rendered new").

title: W.8.9.B
description: Apply grade 8 Reading standards to literary nonfiction (e.g., "Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced").

title: W.9-10.7
description: Conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation.

title: W.9-10.8
description: Gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the usefulness of each source in answering the research question; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and following a standard format for citation.

title: W.9-10.9
description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

title: W.9-10.9.A
description: Apply grades 9-10 Reading standards to literature (e.g., "Analyze how an author draws on and transforms source material in a specific work [e.g., how Shakespeare treats a theme or topic from Ovid or the Bible or how a later author draws on a play by Shakespeare]").

title: W.9-10.9.B
description: Apply grades 9-10 Reading standards to literary nonfiction (e.g., "Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is valid and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; identify false statements and fallacious reasoning").

title: W.11-12.7
description: Conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation.

title: W.11-12.8
description: Gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and overreliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation.

title: W.11-12.9
description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

title: W.11-12.9.A
description: Apply grades 11-12 Reading standards to literature (e.g., "Demonstrate knowledge of eighteenth-, nineteenth- and early-twentieth-century foundational works of American literature, including how two or more texts from the same period treat similar themes or topics").

title: W.11-12.9.B
description: Apply grades 11-12 Reading standards to literary nonfiction (e.g., "Delineate and evaluate the reasoning in seminal U.S. texts, including the application of constitutional principles and use of legal reasoning [e.g., in U.S. Supreme Court Case majority opinions and dissents] and the premises, purposes, and arguments in works of public advocacy [e.g., The Federalist, presidential addresses]").

title: W.6.10
description: Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences.

title: W.7.10
description: Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences.

title: W.8.10
description: Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences.

title: W.9-10.10
description: Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of tasks, purposes, and audiences.

title: W.11-12.10
description: Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of tasks, purposes, and audiences.

title: SL.6.1
description: Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grade 6 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly.

title: SL.6.1.A
description: Come to discussions prepared, having read or studied required material; explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence on the topic, text, or issue to probe and reflect on ideas under discussion.

title: SL.6.1.B
description: Follow rules for collegial discussions, set specific goals and deadlines, and define individual roles as needed.

title: SL.6.1.C
description: Pose and respond to specific questions with elaboration and detail by making comments that contribute to the topic, text, or issue under discussion.

title: SL.6.1.D
description: Review the key ideas expressed and demonstrate understanding of multiple perspectives through reflection and paraphrasing.

title: SL.6.2
description: Interpret information presented in diverse media and formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) and explain how it contributes to a topic, text, or issue under study.

title: SL.6.3
description: Delineate a speaker's argument and specific claims, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and evidence from claims that are not.

title: SL.7.1
description: Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grade 7 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly.

title: SL.7.1.A
description: Come to discussions prepared, having read or researched material under study; explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence on the topic, text, or issue to probe and reflect on ideas under discussion.

title: SL.7.1.B
description: Follow rules for collegial discussions, track progress toward specific goals and deadlines, and define individual roles as needed.

title: SL.7.1.C
description: Pose questions that elicit elaboration and respond to others' questions and comments with relevant observations and ideas that bring the discussion back on topic as needed.

title: SL.7.1.D
description: Acknowledge new information expressed by others and, when warranted, modify their own views.

title: SL.7.2
description: Analyze the main ideas and supporting details presented in diverse media and formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) and explain how the ideas clarify a topic, text, or issue under study.

title: SL.7.3
description: Delineate a speaker's argument and specific claims, evaluating the soundness of the reasoning and the relevance and sufficiency of the evidence.

title: SL.8.1
description: Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grade 8 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly.

title: SL.8.1.A
description: Come to discussions prepared, having read or researched material under study; explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence on the topic, text, or issue to probe and reflect on ideas under discussion.

title: SL.8.1.B
description: Follow rules for collegial discussions and decision-making, track progress toward specific goals and deadlines, and define individual roles as needed.

title: SL.8.1.C
description: Pose questions that connect the ideas of several speakers and respond to others' questions and comments with relevant evidence, observations, and ideas.

title: SL.8.1.D
description: Acknowledge new information expressed by others, and, when warranted, qualify or justify their own views in light of the evidence presented.

title: SL.8.2
description: Analyze the purpose of information presented in diverse media and formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) and evaluate the motives (e.g., social, commercial, political) behind its presentation.

title: SL.8.3
description: Delineate a speaker's argument and specific claims, evaluating the soundness of the reasoning and relevance and sufficiency of the evidence and identifying when irrelevant evidence is introduced.

title: SL.9-10.1
description: Initiate and participate effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grades 9-10 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly and persuasively.

title: SL.9-10.1.A
description: Come to discussions prepared, having read and researched material under study; explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence from texts and other research on the topic or issue to stimulate a thoughtful, well-reasoned exchange of ideas.

title: SL.9-10.1.B
description: Work with peers to set rules for collegial discussions and decision-making (e.g., informal consensus, taking votes on key issues, presentation of alternate views), clear goals and deadlines, and individual roles as needed.

title: SL.9-10.1.C
description: Propel conversations by posing and responding to questions that relate the current discussion to broader themes or larger ideas; actively incorporate others into the discussion; and clarify, verify, or challenge ideas and conclusions.

title: SL.9-10.1.D
description: Respond thoughtfully to diverse perspectives, summarize points of agreement and disagreement, and, when warranted, qualify or justify their own views and understanding and make new connections in light of the evidence and reasoning presented.

title: SL.9-10.2
description: Integrate multiple sources of information presented in diverse media or formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) evaluating the credibility and accuracy of each source.

title: SL.9-10.3
description: Evaluate a speaker's point of view, reasoning, and use of evidence and rhetoric, identifying any fallacious reasoning or exaggerated or distorted evidence.

title: SL.11-12.1
description: Initiate and participate effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grades 11-12 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly and persuasively.

title: SL.11-12.1.A
description: Come to discussions prepared, having read and researched material under study; explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence from texts and other research on the topic or issue to stimulate a thoughtful, well-reasoned exchange of ideas.

title: SL.11-12.1.B
description: Work with peers to promote civil, democratic discussions and decision-making, set clear goals and deadlines, and establish individual roles as needed.

title: SL.11-12.1.C
description: Propel conversations by posing and responding to questions that probe reasoning and evidence; ensure a hearing for a full range of positions on a topic or issue; clarify, verify, or challenge ideas and conclusions; and promote divergent and creative perspectives.

title: SL.11-12.1.D
description: Respond thoughtfully to diverse perspectives; synthesize comments, claims, and evidence made on all sides of an issue; resolve contradictions when possible; and determine what additional information or research is required to deepen the investigation or complete the task.

title: SL.11-12.2
description: Integrate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) in order to make informed decisions and solve problems, evaluating the credibility and accuracy of each source and noting any discrepancies among the data.

title: SL.11-12.3
description: Evaluate a speaker's point of view, reasoning, and use of evidence and rhetoric, assessing the stance, premises, links among ideas, word choice, points of emphasis, and tone used.

title: SL.6.4
description: Present claims and findings, sequencing ideas logically and using pertinent descriptions, facts, and details to accentuate main ideas or themes; use appropriate eye contact, adequate volume, and clear pronunciation.

title: SL.6.5
description: Include multimedia components (e.g., graphics, images, music, sound) and visual displays in presentations to clarify information.

title: SL.6.6
description: Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating command of formal English when indicated or appropriate. (See grade 6 Language standards 1 and 3 for specific expectations.)

title: SL.7.4
description: Present claims and findings, emphasizing salient points in a focused, coherent manner with pertinent descriptions, facts, details, and examples; use appropriate eye contact, adequate volume, and clear pronunciation.

title: SL.7.5
description: Include multimedia components and visual displays in presentations to clarify claims and findings and emphasize salient points.

title: SL.7.6
description: Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating command of formal English when indicated or appropriate. (See grade 7 Language standards 1 and 3 here for specific expectations.)

title: SL.8.4
description: Present claims and findings, emphasizing salient points in a focused, coherent manner with relevant evidence, sound valid reasoning, and well-chosen details; use appropriate eye contact, adequate volume, and clear pronunciation.

title: SL.8.5
description: Integrate multimedia and visual displays into presentations to clarify information, strengthen claims and evidence, and add interest.

title: SL.8.6
description: Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating command of formal English when indicated or appropriate. (See grade 8 Language standards 1 and 3 here for specific expectations.)

title: SL.9-10.4
description: Present information, findings, and supporting evidence clearly, concisely, and logically such that listeners can follow the line of reasoning and the organization, development, substance, and style are appropriate to purpose, audience, and task.

title: SL.9-10.5
description: Make strategic use of digital media (e.g., textual, graphical, audio, visual, and interactive elements) in presentations to enhance understanding of findings, reasoning, and evidence and to add interest.

title: SL.9-10.6
description: Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating command of formal English when indicated or appropriate. (See grades 9-10 Language standards 1 and 3 here for specific expectations.)

title: SL.11-12.4
description: Present information, findings, and supporting evidence, conveying a clear and distinct perspective, such that listeners can follow the line of reasoning, alternative or opposing perspectives are addressed, and the organization, development, substance, and style are appropriate to purpose, audience, and a range of formal and informal tasks.

title: SL.11-12.5
description: Make strategic use of digital media (e.g., textual, graphical, audio, visual, and interactive elements) in presentations to enhance understanding of findings, reasoning, and evidence and to add interest.

title: SL.11-12.6
description: Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating a command of formal English when indicated or appropriate. (See grades 11-12 Language standards 1 and 3 here for specific expectations.)

title: L.6.1
description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

title: L.6.1.A
description: Ensure that pronouns are in the proper case (subjective, objective, possessive).

title: L.6.1.B
description: Use intensive pronouns (e.g., myself, ourselves).

title: L.6.1.C
description: Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in pronoun number and person.

title: L.6.1.D
description: Recognize and correct vague pronouns (i.e., ones with unclear or ambiguous antecedents).

title: L.6.1.E
description: Recognize variations from standard English in their own and others' writing and speaking, and identify and use strategies to improve expression in conventional language.

title: L.6.2
description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

title: L.6.2.A
description: Use punctuation (commas, parentheses, dashes) to set off nonrestrictive/parenthetical elements.

title: L.6.2.B
description: Spell correctly.

title: L.7.1
description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

title: L.7.1.A
description: Explain the function of phrases and clauses in general and their function in specific sentences.

title: L.7.1.B
description: Choose among simple, compound, complex, and compound-complex sentences to signal differing relationships among ideas.

title: L.7.1.C
description: Place phrases and clauses within a sentence, recognizing and correcting misplaced and dangling modifiers.

title: L.7.2
description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

title: L.7.2.A
description: Use a comma to separate coordinate adjectives (e.g., It was a fascinating, enjoyable movie but not He wore an old[,] green shirt).

title: L.7.2.B
description: Spell correctly.

title: L.8.1
description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

title: L.8.1.A
description: Explain the function of verbals (gerunds, participles, infinitives) in general and their function in particular sentences.

title: L.8.1.B
description: Form and use verbs in the active and passive voice.

title: L.8.1.C
description: Form and use verbs in the indicative, imperative, interrogative, conditional, and subjunctive mood.

title: L.8.1.D
description: Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb voice and mood.

title: L.8.2
description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

title: L.8.2.A
description: Use punctuation (comma, ellipsis, dash) to indicate a pause or break.

title: L.8.2.B
description: Use an ellipsis to indicate an omission.

title: L.8.2.C
description: Spell correctly.

title: L.9-10.1
description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

title: L.9-10.1.A
description: Use parallel structure.

title: L.9-10.1.B
description: Use various types of phrases (noun, verb, adjectival, adverbial, participial, prepositional, absolute) and clauses (independent, dependent; noun, relative, adverbial) to convey specific meanings and add variety and interest to writing or presentations.

title: L.9-10.2
description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

title: L.9-10.2.A
description: Use a semicolon (and perhaps a conjunctive adverb) to link two or more closely related independent clauses.

title: L.9-10.2.B
description: Use a colon to introduce a list or quotation.

title: L.9-10.2.C
description: Spell correctly.

title: L.11-12.1
description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

title: L.11-12.1.A
description: Apply the understanding that usage is a matter of convention, can change over time, and is sometimes contested.

title: L.11-12.1.B
description: Resolve issues of complex or contested usage, consulting references (e.g., Merriam-Webster's Dictionary of English Usage, Garner's Modern American Usage) as needed.

title: L.11-12.2
description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

title: L.11-12.2.A
description: Observe hyphenation conventions.

title: L.11-12.2.B
description: Spell correctly.

title: L.6.3
description: Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

title: L.6.3.A
description: Vary sentence patterns for meaning, reader/listener interest, and style.

title: L.6.3.B
description: Maintain consistency in style and tone.

title: L.7.3
description: Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

title: L.7.3.A
description: Choose language that expresses ideas precisely and concisely, recognizing and eliminating wordiness and redundancy.

title: L.8.3
description: Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

title: L.8.3.A
description: Use verbs in the active and passive voice and in the conditional and subjunctive mood to achieve particular effects (e.g., emphasizing the actor or the action; expressing uncertainty or describing a state contrary to fact).

title: L.9-10.3
description: Apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening.

title: L.9-10.3.A
description: Write and edit work so that it conforms to the guidelines in a style manual (e.g., MLA Handbook, Turabian's Manual for Writers) appropriate for the discipline and writing type.

title: L.11-12.3
description: Apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening.

title: L.11-12.3.A
description: Vary syntax for effect, consulting references (e.g., Tufte's Artful Sentences) for guidance as needed; apply an understanding of syntax to the study of complex texts when reading.

title: L.6.4
description: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 6 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

title: L.6.4.A
description: Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence or paragraph; a word's position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

title: L.6.4.B
description: Use common, grade-appropriate Greek or Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a word (e.g., audience, auditory, audible).

title: L.6.4.C
description: Consult reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its precise meaning or its part of speech.

title: L.6.4.D
description: Verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a word or phrase (e.g., by checking the inferred meaning in context or in a dictionary).

title: L.6.5
description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

title: L.6.5.A
description: Interpret figures of speech (e.g., personification) in context.

title: L.6.5.B
description: Use the relationship between particular words (e.g., cause/effect, part/whole, item/category) to better understand each of the words.

title: L.6.5.C
description: Distinguish among the connotations (associations) of words with similar denotations (definitions) (e.g., stingy, scrimping, economical, unwasteful, thrifty).

title: L.6.6
description: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.
